INT SAN SIMEON. ASSEMBLY ROOM NIGHT
INT SAN SIMEON. SCREENING ROOM NIGHT
OF THE PRESS TO COMFORT THE AFFLICTED AND AFFLICT THE
INT CHASEN'S RESTAURANT. PRIVATE ROOM DAY
INT SAN SIMEON. ROMAN POOL NIGHT
INT RKO BOARD ROOM. NEW YORK DAY
INT. ELIZABETH ARDEN SALON. BEVERLY HILLS DAY
INT LONG HALLWAY. NEW YORK DAY
INT MANK'S HOUSE. SANTA MONICA DAY
INT SAN SIMEOM. MARION'S BEDROOM DAY
EXT PALACE THEATER. NEW YORK NIGHT
INT SAN SIMEON, ASSEMBLY ROOM DAY
INT HOTEL ROOM. NEW YORK NIGHT
INT SAN SIMEON. ASSEMBLY ROOM DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few sound engineers and mixers work over recording pane Hermann and the orchestra as Welles, Toland and Mank ente

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read Louella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles shudders

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I can imagine. What am I today? A "puny  upstart" or a "spoiled dilettante" -- no, she  wouldn't know how to spell that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads) "And how is the country to feel when this industry  continues to employ bedraggled foreigners and  swarthy refugees instead of real Americans? Doesn't  Hollywood know there's a Depression on? Don't real  Americans deserve work?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Well, at least she's off KANE today

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No she's not. Don't you get it, ya lunk? She's  using code language to the studio bosses.  "Bedraggled foreigners and swarthy refugees" -- who  the hell do you think she's talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playfully) Hedy Lamarr?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jews. She's talking about Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles' smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who owns this town? Who runs every goddamn studio?  The tribe, baby. These fuckers hear the word "Jew"  and they start sweating. Like Ester Williams' pool  they start sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (growing tense) So they're Jews. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just the first shot. Maestro. Sooner or  later she's gonna use the word. And all those boys  know that there is only one thing this country hates  more than the coloreds and that's the Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, I'm proud to be a Jew, I got no problem. You  don't like it, fuck you. But with these guys it's  like a dirty word. All they wanna be is good red- white-and-blue Americans, and the way they see it  you can't be a good American and a Jew. So Sam  Goldfish becomes Sam Goldwyn and David Selznick  becomes David 0. Selznick -- like anyone's gonna  think he's Irish for fuck's sake--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this have to do with--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead serious) Believe you me, they're gonna do anything -- and I  mean absolutely anything -- to stop that word from  gettin' out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) What?! Are they going to kill me? Is that what  they're going to do?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the sound technicians turns to Welles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND TECHNICIAN Sorry, Mr. Welles, I can't really hear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles, Mank and Toland quickly decamp to a hallway outsi recording stage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge into the hallway. Mank lights a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Let me tell you a story, son  So this was 1924,  right? Hearst was throwing a birthday party for  Thomas Ince, the old movie producer. They were all  on the old man's yacht taking a nice jaunt from  Pedro down to San Diego. Real foggy night it was.  This was Hearst, Marion, Ince, Charlie Chaplin,  Louella, the usual gorillas. So Hearst notices  Marion slip off with Chaplin -- she was screwing  everyone then -- and the old man goes nuts. Grabs  his revolver and starts shooting. Just like Tom Mix,  standing there blasting away through the fog. Boom - - boom -- boom -- and Thomas Ince takes a bullet  through the head. So now there's this dead guy lying  on the deck. You'll see how this could be quite an  embarrassment. So the empire goes into action. Nice  and quiet and Ince was cremated lickety-split. No  inquest and no police. It was right after this that  Hearst gives Louella her life-time contract. Just to  keep her all hush-hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as Mank gazes at Welles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he had known about KANE before you made it,  you'd be dead already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) It's too late. The movie's made

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't let it out. Not Hearst. Not the other  studio heads--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wrote the damn thing, Mank Aren't you going to  fight for it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) I told you this was going to happen! I told you he  was going to come after us! So we took the chance  anyway and we lost. That's how it goes, okay? I got  my check, kid, and so did you -- and that's what  it's all about -- so fuck it and move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles leans forward in a sudden explosion of anger

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I WILL NOT MOVE ON! Let them do their worst! These  petty tyrants! These monstrous, small men Do they  think they can stop us? I Who are they?! Who are  they?! THEY ARE . .. ACCOUNTANTS I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard Hermann appears at a doorway from the recording s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ready. You want to hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles goes with Hermann into the stage. Toland and Mank silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His next picture ... he wants to play Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope he's planning to start with the crucifixion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits at the back of the stage, deep in thought

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard Hermann raises his baton and prepares to conduct. shots of KANE -- fog shrouded Xanadu -- are projected on Hermann conducts and the orchestra plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch the first images of the film with the brilliant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back to reveal we are at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst and Marion are sitting in the plush San Simeon scr surrounded by a passel of dachshunds. Five or six friends spread around the room. Joe Willicombe is also present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch their faces as they watch CITIZEN KANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this sequence we hear bits and pieces of KANE as w and Marion react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Marion's initial amusement give way to a forced ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Hearst becoming increasingly uncomfortable, reacti almost writhing, as his soul is laid bare. Then his face Drained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Joe Willicombe, offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the other guests, horrified and afraid to even so at Hearst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, we hear the ending of the movie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Throw that junk in, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Bernard Hermann's closing music begin to play out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst abruptly stands, the final images of the film wash face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Switch it off SWITCH IT OFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film suddenly stops and lights come up around the scr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence No one looks at Hearst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Would everyone please leave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests and Joe Willicombe solemnly file out A pause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- he got us, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands and goes quickly to pour a drink. A forced lau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nailed us, hub? The crazy old man and his whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bought and p-p-paid for. Just like one of his  goddamn statues. Well at least in the movie he  married her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This picture--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deeply) I am not that woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I could have been. I know what I gave up to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pained) I mean he's even got the goddamn jigsaw puzzles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dissolves into sobs. He cradles her in the empty scre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did he do that to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst is as we have never seen him before. He is in a ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He paces back and forth violently like a caged animal, be increasingly manic and uncontrolled, clenching his fists Joe Willicombe:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now of all times -- NOW -- when I am grasping  on with my fingernails to live at all this Orson We  lies -- this insect -- this reprehensible insect --  has the nerve TO CHALLENGE ME! To show my life as  some cheap sideshow -- A FREAK SHOW -- A DYING,  IMPOTENT OLD FREAK IN HIS CASTLE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smashes a collection of figurines and sends them saili room. Hearst's rage gives way to a darker passion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intensely) Mr. Willicombe -- you have seen me in adversity --  you have seen me take on the unions and the Congress  and the railroads -- and we have risen above -- we  have risen above. And if that dog Welles thinks he  can strike at me now -- when he thinks I'm weak when  he thinks I'm vulnerable -- then he does not fully  comprehend the man is facing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLICOMBE Mr. Welles can't know anything about the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: difficulties  we're--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me Louella Parsons, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willicombe picks up a phone and begins dialing as Hearst

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This upstart -- this puny man -- how does he even  dare to imagine he could comprehend my life and my  world when he crawls with the other insects in the  sewer -- in the dung -- when we control every moment  of his life from the instant he is born to the  instant we decide that he will die! Does he have no  idea of the power that controls him?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hearst, I have Miss Par'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst snatches the phone from Willicombe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Miss Parsons, Mr. Hearst. Use the file

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams down the phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get me J. Edgar Hoover

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLICOMBE It's very late in Washington-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then wake him up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willicombe begins to dial

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fervently) That insect thinks he knows me! He thinks he knows  my capabilities! When his neck is in my teeth and  his blood is in my throat then he will know WILLIAM  RANDOLPH HEARST!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis B. Mayor's eyes are blinking behind his glasses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his glasses we can see vague reflections of a series o photographs showing sex acts and illicit assignations and mug shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back to reveal Mayer flipping through a stack of notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louella sits, smoking and supremely confident, across fro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayer finally closes the file and removes his glasses. He eyes. He rises unsteadily and goes to a liquor cabinet an himself a stiff drink. He gulps it down and then returns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause and then he finally looks at Louella

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do we got here, L.B.? We got faggots and  commies and junkies. We got movie stars screwing  niggers and little girls. We got killers and  perverts and whores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got MGM and Warner Brothers and Columbia and  Disney and Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got Jews

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill CITIZEN KANE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boss is working on some stuff and I'm working  on some stuff. Now I want all you boys working on  some stuff. Cause if it looks like this picture's  ever gonna come out -- I start running down the  street with these pictures like a screaming woman  with my throat cut, you follow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bulldog-like FBI Director HOOVER sits erect at his desk. imposing FBI Seal catches the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses a button on his intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent McCabe, if you please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His secretary, clean-cut FBI agent McCABE, enters quickly pad. Agent McCabe scribbles as Hoover dictates:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open a new file. Heading: Welles, Orson. Native  born. Communist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and Joe Willicombe sit in deck chairs under the bl Marion absently pets a dachshund in her lap. Servants sta with lunch and trays of iced tea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch Hearst riding a horse in the distance A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Davies--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Joe. How bad is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's finished

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst gallops up to them. A servant helps him down from strides briskly to Marion and Willicombe as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about the Tribune in Chicago.  The Examiner just can't make any headway.  Circulation is still down. I think we should buy the  Tribune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion glances to Willicombe and then looks at Hearst wit tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Pops. That's a swell idea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manks pounding away at a typewriter in his tiny beach hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grumbles to himself as he types:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and Rita Hayworth says: "You see, he truly was  the Son of God" ... big Toland lighting effect ...  blah, blah, blah ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock at the door. Mank answers it. Clean-cut FBI Agent outside. He flashes his badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Mr. Mankiewicz, I'm Special Agent McCabe of the  Federal Bureau of Investigation. Might I have a  moment of your time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, kid, come in. I'm writing the crucifixion and  it's a bitch. Sit down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent McCabe sits and snaps open a note pad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  I would like to ask you a few questions about Mr.  Welles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys after Orson too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Mr. Mankiewicz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Are you aware of Mr. Welles' Communist  affiliations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, Orson's no pink. He's everything else under  the sun, but he's no pink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Are you aware of Mr. Welles' Communist  affiliations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I am not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Do you have any knowledge of Communists working  within the motion picture industry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Do you have any knowledge of Communists working  within the motion picture industry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Are you now or have you ever been a member of, or  affiliated with, the Communist Party or any of its  front organizations in the United States?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Are you now or have you ever been a member of--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you better leave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  Are you now or have you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim) Get the fuck outta my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent McCabe snaps his note pad closed and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT McCABE  (crisply) Thank you for your time, Mr. Mankiewicz. We'll be  in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent McCabe leaves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him) Don't bother, you low-life prick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mank slams the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands for a moment, pale, and then goes to the kitche himself a stiff drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion is pouring a drink as well. She quickly fills a gl and then begins striding back and forth across the Assemb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst sits quietly at one of the jigsaw puzzles He occas absently puts a piece in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has clearly been at him for some time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you explain it to me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to explain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A million dollars a year on art and st-st-statues  and there's nothing to explain?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not defend my life to you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to defend anything. But we're in  a pickle and we gotta talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in no "pickle" -- as you would  euphemistically have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta wake up now. Pops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing to discuss-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have any money left, okay?! That's the  truth. I don't wanna say it, nobody else will say  it, but it's the truth. You spent it all. You can't  buy the Tribune in Chicago -- you can't buy ^ g-g- goddamn thing. Now you better face up to it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are being typically theatrical, Marion. I need  the Tribune to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need it! That's the problem you always  think you need everything--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion spins to a medieval arras cloth hanging from one w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That -- did you need that? How much did that cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 12th Century. From Deauville -- in France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where Deauville is for C-C-Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't use that language with me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you need it? Did you need any of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a different between want and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly) Not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) But why? Just so you can show it all off -- just so  everyone can see what a b-b-big man you are?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands quickly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) That's right. You've captured me exactly.  Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not walk out on me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are repellant when you drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough shit. We need to t-t-talk about this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are slovenly and unattractive and I won't (he  mercilessly mimics her) t-t-t-tolerate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (darkly) I will not have this in my home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to understand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) No, you don't. You want to condemn me, like  everyone else. You want to point to the pathetic,  old man grown lunatic with his spending -- trapped  in his ridiculous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: castle -- still fighting old battles he will never  win with Pulitzer and Roosevelt and Hollywood--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing to understand but this:   I am a  man who could have been great, but was not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent scene as we see Marion rummaging through some dr vanity table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A suitcase can be seen on the bed behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She removes various jewelry cases and pours an astounding into a black leather pouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion sits with Carole Lombard in a secluded section of salon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I met him I was just 20. And he was 55. I saw  the gold ring and just grabbed on. And he was going  to make me a star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was making movies I kept begging him to let  me do comedies. Silly stuff, you know. But Pops  doesn't get comedy too well so he kept putting me in  all those godawful p-p-period dramas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carole Lombard smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did my best but, well, you know me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing that bothers me now, though, looking back is  that I really think I could have been something ...  special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking like that is only gonna drive you nuts You  were a great star and you had a good run. That  oughta be enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But all of a sudden it's not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this CITIZEN KANE picture? About Pops and  everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The character that's supposed to be me, Susan  Alexander--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion, everyone knows you're not like that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I am That's the killer, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This little girl comes from nowhere and gets discovered b And maybe she has some real talent way deep down. But he and he makes the decisions. And somewhere along the way . lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hell when you gotta look back and say,  goddamn, what I could have been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion enters a posh Beverly Hills jewelry shop. She is w sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nervously goes to the counter and the SHOP OWNER glid Marion, the entire experience is humiliating. This result stutter becoming increasingly more pronounced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, um, need an estimate on some jewelry I might  wish to sell. But d-d-discretion is very important  to me b-b-because I don't want anyone t-t-to, um,  know that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I hope this isn't rude, but aren't you  Marion Davies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is a great pleasure. Miss Davies! I just  saw that ENCHANTMENT is playing at a the Tivoli, the  revival house in Santa Monica. That was a fine  picture!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one of them today has what you had, Miss  Davies. Not one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you -- b-b-but I'd really like t-t-to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, of course. How can we be of service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said I have some j-j-j-j- (she simply can't  get the word out) that I might wish t-t-to sell and  I wanted an estimate--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely My pleasure, Miss Davies..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion removes the leather pouch from her purse and pours collection of jewelry on a black felt tablet on the count

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awed) My Lord. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion removes her sunglasses and looks at him. Her eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much for the lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is pursuing Schaefer as they stride through the bu backlot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do, Orson? Radio City won't  premiere the picture. Louella threatened them with  some bullshit about

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then find another theater

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I've tried? No one is willing to  open the picture

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll open it in Detroit or Dallas or  Kalamazoo for God's sake! We'll show it in goddamn  circus tents and--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. The press ban is killing us and the  distributors won't book it. And meantime I'm dealing  with the stockholders in New York who are scared  shitless -- and I'm this far from getting fired  myself -- and you don't have a friend in the world  but me right now. So you have got to trust that I'll  do what I can to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately) "Do what you can"?! That's not good enough I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it' s all you've got !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) You're with them, aren't you? You're going to bury  my movie. They bought you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning away) For Christ's sake, shut up--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just have the guts to admit it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spinning on him) How dare you talk to me like that! Do you think I'm  like all the rest of those pirates?! Like Mayer and  Warner? Is that what you think--?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that my movie is so-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely) "Your movie" -- I am so sick of that! It's your  movie -- but it's his life! Did you ever think about  that?! Did you ever think about that old man and  Marion having to watch as you tore them apart?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you every think for one second that you might  have some responsibility for what you're doing?! For  cutting and slashing everything in your way so you  can have your goddamn movie?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That soulless monster gets no tears from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you trying to kid? You are that  soulless monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer turns and stomps away Welles stands, lost for a dream factory

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a bit of a daze, Welles slowly begins walking through bustle of loud activity in a corner of the lot draws his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bulldozer and a dozen workmen are busy tearing down the large white mansion. They strip the wood off and toss it incinerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sees Schaefer standing before all this activity, d thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles goes to him and they stand together in silence for they watch the house being razed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recognize

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles shakes his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Tara. From GONE WITH THE WIND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause as they watch Scarlett O'Hara's dream mansion being

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ... sad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. It's only a set, after all Just lumber.  .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You know, we make all these pictures, we turn em  out one after another, without thinking most of the  time. Just like making toasters or Packards or  toothpaste. But then sometimes ... something amazing  happens and you get a GONE WITH THE WIND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a CITIZEN KANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no one can ever take that away from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gaze at the destruction of Tara as we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and in financial news, rumors continue to swirl  around the head of publishing baron William Randolph  Hearst. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst sits in a wicker chair by the shimmering in-door R for Hearst and the single chair, the pool is deserted and furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst is staring at the gold and blue mosaic of tiles re water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Sources report that the Hearst Empire is  facing some rocky times ahead as the press lord is  facing mounting debts and shrinking revenues due to  over expansion and fiscal mismanagement that have  resulted in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio voice fades to silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silence continues but for the haunting echo of a lion the distance. Then Hearst hears the sound of footsteps ec tile. He looks up. It is Marion. She walks around the poo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a word she hands him a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is made out to William Randolph Hearst in the amount o dollars and is signed Marion Davies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause. He looks up at her, profoundly moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started out as a gold-digger, ya know But goddamn  if I didn't fall in love with the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of six shining limousines are lined up in front of enormous house. The chauffeurs stand together and chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayer sits in the glorious back garden of his house. Six gathered around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayer nods his head to each as we pan around the faces

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Zanuck ... Mr. Warner ... Mr. Cohn Mr. Disney  .. . Mr. Goldwyn . . . Mr. Selznick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you all for coming. You got my memo. What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a fucking punk, why does Hearst give a shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's enough that he does

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would Louella really do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a New York minute

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say to hell with Louella and to hell with Hearst!  Bring 'em on. We can take em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all didn't make GONE WITH THE WIND, ya know.  Some of us gotta look at this checkbook-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who isn't hurting already? All this Jew talk and  these Communist rumors. Look, he's boycotting RKO  ads right now -- but how long before he takes on  Warners or Fox or Columbia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if Hearst goes public with all this filthy  private lives stuff, Hollywood's sunk. He's got us  nailed. Dates. Times. Photographs for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to be funny, but what could he have on  Mickey Mouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got you so tied in with J. Edgar Hoover and  America First that you might as well put on a brown  shirt and kiss those happy little kiddies so-long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Have any of you actually seen the movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have. It's probably the greatest motion picture  ever made. Nothing's going to be the same after  this. With this one movie he's changed the way we  see--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. And so should all of you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off the soapbox--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Selznick stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want no part of this. We should be marching into  George Schaefer's office and standing with him. He's  one of us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I ever got into trouble I'd like to think that  you all would be with me -- not planning to stab me  in the back like a bunch of ... a bunch of ...  producers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He storms off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mayer) Your son-in-law meshuaena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) He's got me and Hoover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Walt, at least he don't have you screwing  Snow White. I got fucking Errol Flynn on my payroll!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mayer) You're a smart man, L.B. I suspect you would not  have called us here without a plan. Give over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will buy the movie and we will destroy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will assemble a fund between us -- privately,  'not studio money -- we will assemble this fund and  we will go to George Schaefer and we will buy the  negative and every print of CITIZEN KANE and we will  burn them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I do not hear an objection to this agenda in the  next five seconds I will assume the motion has  carried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five seconds tick by as we focus on the titans of Hollywo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, my associates will be in touch to  arrange payment. Thank you for your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE composer Bernard Hermann again stands before the orc arm poised, waiting to begin conducting. He is about to r music for the deep-focus Thatcher/Bernstein/Kane scene fr KANE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits nearby, supervising everything. Welles nods a screen the scene from KANE begins and Hermann starts cond orchestra plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music carries into and gradually fades during.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a scene eerily reminiscent of the Thatcher/Bernstein/K Marion sits in the extreme foreground, a man we do not kn middle distance at a desk and Hearst stands far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst has his back to them and stares out a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new man is MR. LEWIS, a tight banker from New York, 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over a thick legal document on the desk as he sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEWIS You will retain some editorial control over the rem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: newspapers but the actual ownership will go to the Conser Committee and the banks. We will be immediately closing 1 papers and the wire services. And we will be liquidating as soon as possible. Most of the land in Mexico as well a collection of art and antiquities--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Mr. Hearst spent his life collecting that art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) We've been in touch with Gimbels in New York and  they've agreed to hold a special sale. They're  giving over an entire floor for the merchandise.  You'll have to go there in person to sign the bill  of sale, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, not turning) I'll have to sell the animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we don't know whether we'll be able to retain  the castle. The land has some capital and we might  keep it on as an investment. Maybe break it up into  smaller units for housing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause Hearst finally turns and walks to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lewis) When will it come out? When will the public know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't keep it a secret, sir. Once we announce  the Gimbels sale and start liquidating the assets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pained) This is your whole life. Pops. Don't do it. We'll  find another way..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat as he looks at her. Then he quickly signs the the desk. He puts down the pen and leaves the room withou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion sits nestled on a sweeping marble stairway Weeping

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swank benefit dinner is in progress A band plays

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A banner hangs over the nightclub stage: CHILDREN'S MILK 1940

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float through the elegant crowd and spy Louis B. Mayer Clark Gable and Carole Lombard; all manner of movie stars brokers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We also spy Schaefer sitting with Mank and Toland and a f and women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evening's EMCEE takes the stage

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next up we have a real treat. It's Orson Welles.  Now, during the rehearsal for the benefit tonight  Orson banished everyone from the club so he could  proceed in utmost secrecy. But you all know how  Orson is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the crowd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, lets give a big round of applause for Mr. Orson  Welles and Miss Rita Hayworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polite applause as Welles bounds to the stage with RITA H the band begins to play a buoyant tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer practically drops his fork

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is dressed in a padded costume and made up in a wa suggest no one but William Randolph Hearst. Rita Hayworth a manner mightily like Marion Davies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louella glances to Mayer, daggers. Some knowing laughter audience. Particularly Mank

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of chorus girls hoof on and join Welles and Rita H row of harsh footlights snap on, giving the scene a resem "Charlie Kane" dance in CITIZEN KANE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Welles launches into a jaunty song and dance version "DISGUSTINGLY RICH" an almost unknown Rodgers and Hart so has wickedly changed some of the lines. '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'll buy everything I wear at Saks. I'll print  gossip and I'll call it facts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Swear like a trooper, Live in a stupor--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Just disgustingly rich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'll make money and I'll make it quick, Starting  little wars I think are slick. Smother her in  sables, Like Betty Grable's-- Just disgustingly  rich.  "I'll build a castle, That'll cost a passel.  And as a resident, I will pan the president I'll  aspire, Higher and Higher. "I'll get married and  I'll buy a girl, So darn pretty that your head will  swirl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Swimming in highballs-- Stewed to the eyeballs--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Just disgustingly rich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles, Rita Hayworth and the chorines do a nifty soft-sh Schaefer turns to Mank:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously) He truly doesn't care if he ever works again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, ain't it swell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles and Rita Hayworth conclude their little dance brea resumes the song:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ev'ry summer I will sail the sea, On my little  yacht the Normandie, Pet my little dachshund  friends, Kiss Louella's big rear end, Just  disgustingly rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About here Louella storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'll eat salmon, I'll play backgammon. Turn breakfast in I'll take Thomas Ince to lunch I'll aspire, Higher and Hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About here Louis B Mayer and a few others storm out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He'll be photographed with Myrna Loy, Just to  prove he is a glamour boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Perfumed and scented, Slightly demented-- Just  disgustingly rich

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'll get my capers, Into his papers. Hoping his  folly would Lead me out to Hollywood. I'll aspire,  Higher and higher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About here Schaefer buries his face in his hands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In the funnies and the valentines, We'll be  pictured drinking Ballantine's. Dopey and screwy,  Voting for Dewey.  Just disgustingly-- Too, too  disgustingly-- Riiiiich! "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles and Rita Hayworth conclude the number with a big f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some applause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mank stands and applauds loudly. Laughing. Welles bows so

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night, Welles is about to climb into his limou the nightclub with Rita Hayworth when Schaefer suddenly a grabs his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) George- -!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a word, Schaefer pulls Welles roughly into an all nightclub. He slams Welles into the alley wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brutally) This isn' t some kinda fucking game! You know how  many people RKO employs?! You know how many people  depend on what we do for a living?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really think you're

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna commit suicide, fine! You got some death- wish, fine! But you will not drag this company down  with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a -joke, George

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer slaps Welles firmly across the face. Welles is s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no jokes! There are people making a  living. There is food on the table!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer glares at him and then rages off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles straightens his suit and then, with a shaking hand a cigar. He tries to laugh, but cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer sits at his desk, absolutely dazed. Speechless

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B. Mayer sits across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did this money come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 800,000 dollars fully covers the production budget  and a little more. Hell, George, you even make a  profit on the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very generous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we gotta be clear here. I need the negative and  every existing print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for me to decide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to destroy it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, maybe put it on the shelf until the old man  kicks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We already made the same offer to the stockholders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talked to New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talked to Mr. Swanbeck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bettin' on an inside straight this time.  You'll never pull it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayer stands and smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This picture, George, it'll just break your heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayer goes. Schaefer sits, smelling defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We linger on Schaefer as a haunting echo of "I CAN'T GET heard. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float through the estate as we hear the ghostly strain Berigan's recording of "I CAN'T GET STARTED."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a sad journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time many of the ornate antiquities have been rem castle and it resembles Welles' stark and dreary Xanadu a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I've flown around the world in a plane, I've  settled revolutions in Spain, And the North Pole I  have charted, Still I can't get started with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float past the private zoo, now empty, the cages hangi move past the tennis courts, empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "On the golf course I'm under par, Metro Goldwyn  has asked me to star, I've got a house, a show  place, Still I can't get no place with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float into the castle itself and through the stripped- Screening Room and the Assembly Room and the Great Dining

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All are mere shadows of their past glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Cause you're so supreme, Lyrics I write of you, I  dream, dream day and night of you And I scheme just  for the sight of you, Baby, what good does it do...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We finally float into the ballroom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A record of "I CAN'T GET STARTED" spins forlornly on a tu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Marion and Hearst are having a quiet, poignant dance the middle of the empty ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I've been consulted by Franklin D. Greta Garbo has  had me to tea, Still I'm broken hearted Cause I  can't get started with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finally stop dancing and stand swaying gently. Then swaying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Ah, Miss Davies, the times we have seen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds him closely as "I CAN'T GET STARTED" concludes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles has booked a private room at Chasen's. A long banq contains cans of sterno heating various dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large photographs of the American West and renderings fro CHRIST are scattered around other tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles wanders around the renderings with Gregg Toland an carries a plate of food and consumes as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, this is the Great Salt Lake -- we do the  baptism here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great scene where John the Baptist pulls your head  out of the water and says, "Look up, and behold your  destiny"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that from one of the Gospels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George! Enter And Behold

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer blinks at the massive photos and renderings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not still mad at me, I hope

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're jake. But listen-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, not a single scene shot in the studio! We've  found natural locations for the whole story--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on a sec. I got news. We finally found  somewhere to premiere KANE but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you! Where? Grauman's? El Capitan? Or did  Radio City come crawling back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Palace in New York. But Orson there's something  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles stops eating

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you better sit down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) I don't want to sit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bosses -- the other studios -- they want to buy  the film and destroy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolute silence

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They came to me with an offer. 800,000 for the  negative and all the prints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they went to the stockholders in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been talking to Swanbeck in New York and...  Orson, I think they're gonna take it A long pause as  Welles looks at Schaefer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles suddenly FLINGS his plate of food in Schaefer's di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU STUPID, LITTLE MAN! HOW COULD YOU HAVE LET THIS  HAPPEN?! I GAVE YOU MY SOUL AND NOW YOU'RE GOING TO  SELL IT!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't George's doing--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles- rampages around the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I PUT MY LIFE INTO THAT PICTURE -- EVERYTHING I'VE  BEEN -- EVERYTHING I COULD BE---IT'S CITIZEN KANE! - - IT'S ALL CITIZEN KANE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in a screaming, bellowing fury, Welles tears apart th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a scene sharply reminiscent of Kane destroying Susan's Welles rampages around the room, upsetting tables and sma everything in reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles finally grabs a flaming can of sterno and flings i Schaefer knocks it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Welles stands in spent exhaustion, panting. One of h bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Schaefer. A pause. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let . . . me . . . talk to them. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York ... The stockholders

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me one chance. And then you will never have to see m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire two-acre fifth floor of Gimbels is in chaos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large banner is suspended at one end of the floor; "The Collection." It is the first day of the sale and it is mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst and Marion, alone in a crowd, walk wordlessly thro mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere around them hundreds of eager customers strike snatching up useless junk and treasured antiques.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see bits and pieces of San Simeon in the jumble

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass a man and his wife, holding up Marion's -BLESS sampler:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old man Hearst owned this and I'm getting it for  two bits I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst and Marion continue to walk, finally arriving at t containing the true, expensive treasures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst watches as customers pick up and fondle his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at a framed front page of the San Francisco Ex date is March 4, 1887. In a large box on the page is: "IT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't sell this. How much are they asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Pops ... let it go. Just ... let it go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. A long moment. He tenderly touches her f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think I shall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand and leads her away as we pull up and ta entire fifth floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a stunning KANE-like image of rows and rows of merc high. Of junk and jewels. Of Charles Foster Kane and Will Hearst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits brooding in his hotel room. His invincible en gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is deep in thought, listlessly shuffling and reshuffli cards in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He aimlessly shuffles through the cards and plucks one ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six of spades

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at the card. It is the nine of hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuffles through the cards again and pulls out another

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six of spades

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the card. It is the two of clubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His attention is now fully on the cards. He shuffles them and snatches out a card. He looks at it and then tosses i shuffles again, working the trick, again it fails. He tos card away. He continues, ;' more quickly, to attempt the fails again. And ' again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a frightened moan Welles flings the entire deck away bolts out of the room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles emerges from a stairway on the roof of his hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He marches to the edge of the roof and leans against a ra for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere below him the shimmering lights of Manhattan t flash; cabs and neon and noise. The night sky above him i stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks away from the city and up to the stars -- they c fully. He stares and stares at the impossible chaos of be lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long moment as Welles gazes at the stars. The city belo noise seem to disappear and Welles stands, safe and at pe silent dome of stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stars are reflected in his huge, dark eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magically, the stars in his eyes give way to the vague sh sitting around a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles looks at the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back to see we are at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles stands at the head of a long conference table. Tit 1941

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the table are gathered a group of stern businessme also present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles looks at the men. And he speaks. For once, his usu overwrought, theatrical tones are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speaks simply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today a man from Germany invaded Greece. He has  already swallowed Poland and Denmark and Norway and  Belgium. He is bombing London as I speak. Everywhere  this man goes he crushes the life and the freedom of  his subjects. He sews yellow stars onto their  lapels. He takes their voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this country we still have our voices. And we can sing And we can argue with them. And we can be heard. Because for the moment . . . free. No one can tell us what to say it, can they? We have no brown shirt thugs here ruling ou we? No one can take our voices, can they? Because we are

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am one voice and that is all. My picture is one voice. in Europe now -- and Americans soon will be -- so that we the tyrants and the dictators. Will you send a message ac country that one man can take away our voices?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So ... who is Mr. Hearst and who is Mr. Welles? Mr. Hears palace of brick and mortar and starting little wars and c high. I built a palace of illusion. My castle Xanadu is a painting and camera trick. It's nothing but . . . a dream

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today you have a chance to let the dream triumph. For onc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gazes at them and then slowly walks out of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits quietly on a bench in a long hallway in a tal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer emerges from an office and goes to him. He sits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We open on May 1st.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles slowly nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orson, what you said in there. Did you mean it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it matter? They believed it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands and begins walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles stops, not turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles continues down the hall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Title: APRIL 30, 1941 Welles is rushing to catch an eleva doors close

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nips in at the last minute and punches his button. He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator is deserted but for one other person: Willia Hearst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles and Hearst recognize each other instantly. As the ascends the two men look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very long pause as we watch their faces -- the young ma man -- both men of mad grandeur and malevolent passion an inspiration -- both men of incalculable achievement and m poignancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hearst, we've met once before, my name is Orson  Welles and I've got a movie opening tomorrow night  at the Palace. I would be pleased to get you  tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause as Hearst regards Welles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Hearst carefully reaches over and presses the stop b elevator. The elevator stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exceedingly quiet exchange:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder. Do you have any idea what you have done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intimately. For every sin you have placed on my  head I could give you a hundred others. I have been  swimming in blood my entire life. But I retain a  belief, perhaps you will think it old fashioned,  undoubtedly you will, but I believe that private  lives should not be public property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elegant words, sir, when you have made your name  and your fortune on slander and innuendo and gossip.  In your papers you taught the world how to look  under every rock. I learned at the knee of the  master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where does that leave us, Mr. Welles? What kind  of sad future are we two making? A future where men  will do anything to sell their newspapers and their  movies? A future where no price is too high for fame  and power? When we will all scratch each other to  pieces just to be heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you truly envision such ... horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst presses the stop button again and the elevator beg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors opens on Hearst's floor and he leaves the eleva

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors are about to shut on Welles when he leans forwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES FOSTER KANE WOULD HAVE ACCEPTED I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors shut on Welles and we remain with Hearst as he down the long hotel hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks with dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the premiere of CITIZEN KANE, at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Palace Theater swarms with tuxedos and dress gowns as New York and Hollywood descend from limousines and slowly the packed lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the Palace marquee "ORSON WELLES" is spelled out in en foot tall electric letters. Below that is "CITIZEN KANE" electric letters. Above the marquee is a series of toweri neon Charles Foster Kanes and the words "IT'S TERRIFIC."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Title; MAY l, 1941

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float down and enter the crowded lobby with the patron

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We swirl with the throng of patrons in the lobby as they theater and finally find Welles and Schaefer huddled toge in a corner of the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are studiously ignored and snubbed by all the movie filtering past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're cutting us dead, every goddamn one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are ignored by a few more people

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my birthday this week. I'll be 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mank fights through the crowd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monstro! Ran into Walter Winchell outside He wants  to play Herod in the picture. Hiya, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigar) So ain't this just the bee's knees? The high  muckey-mucks dolled up all Aztec-like for the human  sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I know how it ends. (He calls to a passing stranger) Hey, Rosebud's the sled!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face it, Orson, they're gonna hate it. I told you,  not enough closeups and too many scenes with a bunch  of New York actors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pained) Oh God. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, George. It's gonna go great. Trust me. Have  I ever lied to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer looks at him for a moment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something, Orson, you haven't done  anything but lie to me from the moment we met. But,  ya know, I'd do it again in a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was fun, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) It was the best, kid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, on to the Life Of Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without me. I'm afraid. I got the axe this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. Cause you know something..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm an old coot playing dominoes down in Miami Beach from now, I'll say, "Hey, you kids ever heard of a guy na Hearst?" And they'll say, "Nope. Never heard of him." And say, "Hey, you ever heard of a picture called CITIZEN KAN will have. That's enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pats Welles arm and goes into the theater

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) What have I done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, cheer up, George'll probably be running Fox by  the morning. Let's get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mank pulls at Welles' arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the picture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mank stops and looks at him deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Kid, you know how it ends too. It ends sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls Welles away from the theater and down the street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch the faces

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the flickering blue light we watch the audience as we Hermann's evocative and haunting opening music to CITIZEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We slowly move across a sea of faces as the music plays. especially the movie people, what they are seeing is a re revolution. It is a whole new way of seeing the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see their amazement as they are mesmerized -- and thei they are challenged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see George Schaefer, quietly proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard Hermann's opening music continues to play until w hear;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Rosebud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the world of movies is forever changed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles and Mank are sitting in a rundown, deserted bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, all this nightmare we went through with  Hearst. The whole thing... And in the end, probably  no one will ever remember the picture anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're probably right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Mank takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell ya something, kid. When you make your  masterpiece at 26 it's a bitch. I mean. where do you  go from here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Welles speaks, softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will burn. Burn up. Burn out.  But oh, what a flame

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Mank and toasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Orson Welles smiles. Indomitable.
